title: Firefox Auto Crashing
content:
Firefox keeps randomly crashing and won't open, sometimes I can get 10 minutes before it returns to crashing all over again. Doesn't even OPEN troubleshoot mode, it just auto crashes.

My drivers are up to date, my windows are up to date, Firefox is up to date, Internet Security software is up to date. 

I need this running ASAP for work, each crash report has a different code too which hurts.

First crash happened in the afternoon, yesterday. bp-6580ff2f-d79c-4472-89f6-542c60250604 4/06/2025, 5:15 pm

The rest are all today. bp-79fddad8-e05d-4376-884f-f81670250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-d3e94b00-0c80-4db1-94e0-9c1410250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-9191a616-31cc-44e0-83a0-5e0d20250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-18adbdcb-ea8a-44cd-b4a0-18c4e0250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-f27c149e-2355-4632-8d0e-28fcc0250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-cfc523e7-c87f-42ac-bd2e-ddea90250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-bcee28d7-140f-4ad2-846c-308750250604 5/06/2025, 2:05 am bp-500792c2-0995-4a9e-8e87-600ad0250604 5/06/2025, 2:07 am

title: Mac OS 15.5 - Firefox will not open
content:
Firefox will not open on my MacBook Pro. Mac OS 15.5.

Terminal report: 2025-06-04 10:47:20.009 firefox[2076:19473] Server doesn't exist or doesn't provide correct selectors.

Behavior: Clicking Firefox to open results in a window asking for permission to install a new Helper tool. If I grant access I soon see a new window that says the Helper has been installed and I can go to my settings and manage it. Meanwhile the Firefox icon keeps jumping up and down and won't finish opening so I have had to force quit. If I do not grant access to the installation by clicking "cancel" I get the same result: Firefox dances and won't open. I have tried simple solutions like force quitting the dancing icon and restarting after getting the "installed" message. No difference. No difference also if I cancel the installation, force quit and restart.

Please help!
creator: howardkling

title: Firefox is missing a crucial feature.
content: I have been using Firefox for the last 5 years, I have been content with their services and for that reason I keep using it. Lately I had computer issues so I had to reset my computer and start over this includes Firefox as well. Anyhow because of my lifestyle i do different things like school work, farming, and other stuff. Windows has a feature called "Desktops" this feature is very handy to me as it lets me organize my tabs and windows base on the topic like school or work, (To illustrate this I included a picture of how I have it organize.) well, sometimes my computer shuts down by accident or intentional. Regardless if it was shut down by accident or not, I would boot my computer up and lunch Firefox, and Firefox would open my tabs and windows in the Desktop that It was previously at. For example, I would have all of my school related tabs and windows in the School Desktop, and all of my Work related stuff in the work Desktop, after booting Firefox would automatically place my tabs windows in those compartments, well now Firefox doesn't do that anymore and it is frustrating because every time I boot my computer up after an update or a restart, when Firefox is lunch Firefox will place all of my tabs and windows in the first Desktop, and this is frustrating because every time that happens I have spend time on sorting my tabs out to the right compartment, and to be honest I'm getting sick and tired of doing it because i lose time. So to anyone who reads this, can you please help me figure out what is wrong, because if it is a setting then that's is understandable but if it is Firefox then it would break my heart because as an user and a fan It would break my heart to stop using Firefox as my primary app.
creator: sotini0504

title: Firefox seems to update in the background, then accuses me of launching an older version, wiping my bookmarks
content:
I'm running Firefox 139.0.1 on Mac Sonoma 14.7.1.

Since FF V138, I've had this extremely frustrating problem where, approximately once a day and while the application is still running, Firefox seems to either auto-revert to an older version' 'or otherwise mess up the installation files. I don't get any notice this is happening until I try to open a new tab and it brings up the "You must restart Firefox" notice. When I click Restart, it pops up with "You've launched an older version of Firefox, so you won't keep any of your bookmarks because that would be unstable" error.

The only way I've found to fix it is to redownload the most recent install files, which, after the fresh install, will allow me to keep using Firefox with my bookmarks for the next 5-6 hours, before the whole process starts again.

I theoretically have auto-updates off; my settings are set to the other option, "Check for updates but let you choose to install them". Doesn't seem to make a difference. It only does this on my Mac; the FF install on my Windows machine works fine.

I really want to keep using FF. It's my preferred personal browser. But this is really messing with me! I was hopeful that 139.1 would fix it but same issue, so far.
creator: arlinn315

title: Illegal streaming!!
content: Hey team at Firefox, I stream a lot of movies illegaly, animes and shows too on Firefox and one of the most common exploits used by bad people is spyware and injection of malware seems inevitable. even with all the amazing protection features offered by you guys and UBlock origin don't seem enough at all. using a VPN and a amazing browser suite can only go so far. i had the idea of sand-boxing on my PC but a pain to do it every single time and keep a track of everything i am doing. The idea here essentially is to somehow sandbox certain tabs or windows entirely and to be able to pick up where u left off. this paired with the Firefox advanced features and all the amazing extension still available here instead of chrome will make the experience even safer. Hopefully this is something you guys can actually do. More than that i hope this reaches the relevant people at the company not just drowned in a pool of support tickets. I expect no credits or anything like that. I just want to know if its possible and this reach the devs so maybe they make it happen. I do think this is a great idea and a possible feature on here. i can think of more ways to use sandboxing like that but this is just how i want to use it. Kind regards.

title: blob:
content:
Hello,

I process phishing URL's,

I have recently come across URL's that make use of a BLOB: syntax on the URL:

blob:https://bolig.botik.dk/16c8c011-0fa5-4ba0-a10f-ed7675055cc6

You can see an example of the Phishing URL in this PhishTank entry:

https://phishtank.com/phish_detail.php?phish_id=9118779

That URL then re-directs to the above "BLOB" URL.

My understanding is that it is "locally" generating the phishing website, similar to an old fashioned about: syntax, however it's not clear what the significance of bolig.botik.dk URL is - loading that URL without the BLOB: prefix causes an error

Can someone explain:

1) What is the BLOB: syntax, and 2) what would be reported to have the phishing URL removed in the above example?

title: Access Limitation to Specific Site
content:
Full access to one of my favorite websites -- BillO'Reilly.com, which I visit daily -- has been compromised through Firefox. If I access it's home page, it briefly appears in color -- then quickly changes to black and white! This is the case in pages throughout the site. Only O'Reilly's "No Spin News" program comes in color but, only if you're a paid subscriber to the site. The site comes in perfectly on other browsers (e.g. Chrome and Edge) and I have informed the site's technical staff about the issue.

Please look into this.

--Thanks, Steve Saucedo 

  Firefox User Since Its Beginning
creator: slsaucedo3
